Bug report:
 DW ( 6/1/01 8:15:59 AM ) In the self hosting setup , If I create a simple Test project with one `` HelloWorld '' class , and debug that class ( breakpoint on println ) , I do not see source for the HelloWorld class . I am using the default source locating strategy for that project , and a custom strategy for the `` Eclipse Core Launching '' project . If I change to use a `` custom lookup '' with just the one `` Test '' project , source is found . TM ( 6/1/2001 15:24:18 ) I just tried this in 116 . I do this in the package viewer : 1 ) create a new java project `` Test '' , press finish on the first wizard page 2 ) create a class `` Foo '' in the default package , check the box to add a main method 3 ) add System.out.println ( `` foobar '' ) ; to the main method 4 ) add a breakpoint 5 ) build & hit debug 6 ) source of the main method is shown in the debugger . EG ( 6/2/2001 4:43:32 AM ) I ca n't reproduce it either but DM & DB had problems with the source attachment for rt.jar in 117 . The variable settings were correct in their workspaces . EG ( 6/4/2001 12:36:22 AM ) I suspect a race condition . I 'm observing that when a type from a JAR is restored as part of the persistent layout then it can happen that the type does not exist . DW ( 6/4/01 2:14:05 PM ) Tracked this down to a NotPresentException - I have a closed & non-existent project on a classpath . My classpath for `` org.eclipse.jdt.debug '' included `` org.eclipse.jdt.core '' . This happenned because we once had the `` org.eclipse.jdt.core '' project in the workspace as source , but no longer do . By removing the project from my classpath , the problem goes away . However , I do not see why it was even checking the classpath of that project , since the project I was debugging was a simple stand-alone `` HelloWorld '' project . Thread [ main ] ( Suspended ( exception CoreException ) ) JavaProject.openWhenClosed ( IProgressMonitor ) line : 1065 JavaProject ( JavaElement ) .openHierarchy ( ) line : 463 JavaProject ( JavaElement ) .getElementInfo ( ) line : 261 JavaProject.getJavaProjectElementInfo ( ) line : 559 JavaProject.getRawClasspath ( ) line : 780 JavaProject.getResolvedClasspath ( boolean ) line : 798 BuildPathSourceLocator.getProjectsOnClassPath ( IJavaProject ) line : 71 BuildPathSourceLocator.addAllOnClasspath ( List , IJavaProject ) line : 63 BuildPathSourceLocator.addAllOnClasspath ( List , IJavaProject ) line : 65 BuildPathSourceLocator.addAllOnClasspath ( List , IJavaProject ) line : 65 BuildPathSourceLocator.getProjectList ( IJavaProject ) line : 52 BuildPathSourceLocator ( CustomListSourceLocator ) .getSourceElement ( IStackFrame ) line : 42 ProjectSourceLocator.getSourceElement ( IStackFrame ) line : 72 DebugView.showMarkerForCurrentSelection ( ) line : 220 DebugView.selectionChanged ( SelectionChangedEvent ) line : 187 LaunchesViewer ( Viewer ) .fireSelectionChanged ( SelectionChangedEvent ) line : 123 LaunchesViewer ( StructuredViewer ) .updateSelection ( ISelection ) line : 8

314 UIMain.main ( String [ ] ) line : 46 DW ( 6/4/01 2:46:35 PM ) Becuase the ADDITIONAL_LOOKUP_PROPERTY check is returning null , the source lookup degrades to looking in the entire workspace . This property is only set by the '' SourceLookupPropertyPage '' . Generally , the user will never go to this page or change the property , so the source lookup is probably always degrading to looking in the entire workspace . public static IJavaProject [ ] getSourceLookupPath ( IJavaProject project ) throws JavaModelException { IProject p= project.getProject ( ) ; try { String property= p.getPersistentProperty ( new QualifiedName ( LaunchingPlugin.getPluginId ( ) , ADDITIONAL_LOOKUP_PROPERTY ) ) ; if ( property == null ) return null ; return decodeProjects ( property ) ; } catch ( CoreException e ) { throw new JavaModelException ( e ) ; } } EG ( 6/4/2001 10:49:18 AM ) should fix . Source lookup should be robust against non-existing class path entries . JW ( 6/5/01 6:01:03 PM ) OK to fix . TM ( 6/5/2001 11:06:11 ) fixing the original scenario should be easy & safe TM ( 6/6/2001 15:32:50 ) fix is to ignore non-existing & closed projects . fix in the works . TM ( 6/6/2001 15:50:58 ) have fix . TM ( 6/6/2001 16:45:53 ) reviewed by AW . EG ( 23.07.2001 11:19:16 ) pls check that fix is 0.9 TM ( 23.07.2001 11:28:52 ) The fix is in 0.9. moving to verify .

Bug report:
 1 . Add a breakpoint for `` java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException : caught and uncaught '' 2 . Run the code which follows 3 . When the program stops at the illegal index access , select the Main.foo ( ) method in the execution stack display 4 . Go to the Display view and evaluate `` aVector.size ( ) '' Rather than give the correct output ( 1 ) , an exception is thrown : `` java.lang.ClassNotFoundException '' Test code : import java.util . * ; public class Main { private Vector aVector ; public static void main ( String [ ] args ) { new Main ( ) .foo ( ) ; } public Main ( ) { aVector = new Vector ( ) ; } public void foo ( ) { aVector.add ( new Integer ( 1 ) ) ; aVector.elementAt ( -1 ) ; return ; } } NOTES : DW ( 6/18/01 5:00:20 PM ) I found that if the top stack frame is in a binary type , but the selected stack frame is in a source type , I get the same error . I tried Infinite Loop , and stepped into the System.out.println ( ) . From the calling stack frame I did an evaluation of a constant and got a ClassNotFoundException . Not sure why this matters . DW ( 6/19/01 9:23:34 AM ) Defer . OT ( 14/08/2001 4:10:38 PM ) The problem seems to come from the stack frame used for the evaluation . I need to find out which stack frame is used . The top one seems to be a good guess and like this class is classes.zip the bootstrapclassloader is used instead of the classloader . The consequence of this that the code snippet classes are not found . OT ( 23/08/2001 2:29:52 PM ) We should always use the stack frame in which the code is evaluated and not the top one . DW ( 8/28/01 10:20:10 AM ) The stack frame comes from the UI selection in `` EvaluateAction. # getContext ( ) '' . This needs to be debugged . A quick look at the code looks like it should get the selected stack frame properly . DS ( 9/10/01 1:37:59 PM ) The top stack frame is not being used ... the stack frame is the one that the evaluation occurs in . DS ( 9/10/01 4:20:24 PM ) Talking with JW , this is the known problem of not being able to perform evaluations in classes that have been loaded from the BootClassLoader as this loader will not find our snippet class . 

Remembering the instruction:
Categorize the bug report into one of 2 categories:

0 = NOT SEVERE
1 = SEVERE[/INST]

Bug report:
 Place a break point in some class and run it so that you have a thread suspended in the debugger . Open up some other .java files Select text in one of the .java files Note that in the editor of this other file , Inspect , Disply and Run to line are enabled . Likewise in all the .java editors Note that Inspect and Display generally do not do much , typically just stating that the field name could not be resolved . But run to line triggers an action , it causes the selected/suspended thread to run even if you are not in the right editor . NOTES : EG ( 6/14/2001 7:34:42 AM ) the enabling state currently only checks that there is a debugger context . Not critical moving to DUI . DW ( 6/14/01 12:50:53 PM ) Deferred . DW ( 8/15/01 9:55:57 AM ) Duplicate of 1GF7DEK : ITPJUI : WINNT - contextmenu entries do not disappears in editor after snippet evaluation ( Closed Dup ) . 

Remembering the instruction:

0 = NOT SEVERE
1 = SEVERE[/INST]

Bug report:
 DW ( 9/21/2001 3:52:58 PM ) Drop to frame occurrs even though a type was not reloaded . Using J9 . 1 ) Set a breakpoint in `` DropTests '' , on the `` System.println ... '' method ( in method4 ( ) ) 2 ) Debug , and when the breakpoint is hit remove the closing quote from the println , introducing a syntax error . 3 ) Save 4 ) The syntax error appears , and the debugger performs a drop to frame even though there are compilation errors in the type and it was not reloaded . DW ( 9/21/2001 3:56:34 PM ) If a CU has compilation errors , we should not attempt a re-load . Or , we should only drop those frames for which re-load was successful .

1 = SEVERE[/INST]

(1, 0).description: DW ( 9/21/2001 3:52:58 PM ) Drop to frame occurrs even though a type was not reloaded . Using J9 . 1 ) Set a breakpoint in `` DropTests '' , on the `` System.println ... '' method ( in method4 ( ) ) 2 ) Debug , and when the breakpoint is hit remove the closing quote from the println , introducing a syntax error . 3 ) Save 4 ) The syntax error appears , and the debugger performs a drop to frame even though there are compilation errors in the type and it was not reloaded . DW ( 9/21/2001 3:56:34 PM ) If a CU has compilation errors , we should not attempt a re-load . Or , we should only drop those frames for which re-load was successful .

Bug report:
 DBCS-PDE : Source Page for the Plug-in Manifest editor does not display correct DBCS char . What was displayed look like correct DBCS char but in reality they are corrupted DBCs char . Steps to recreate : ( Test case 2 : Plug-in Development : Adding New Action Set extension point and New Top level menu ) -Create a plug-in project : File- > New- > Project ... and selecting Plug-in Development , then Plug-in Project , press next . - create Action Sets and Menu with DBCS in its label field . - After changing the label to DBCS using properties view , check the source page and make sure that the characters are not corrupted . Characters in editor ( source page ) was corrupted DBCS . Due to the corrupted characters , it could n't be compiled . Verify that the menu label shows up correctly in the menu bar in run-time workspace . - < ? xml version= '' 1.0 '' encoding= '' UTF-8 '' ? > < actionSet label= '' ( dbcs ) '' visible= '' true '' id= '' j.actionSet2 '' > < menu label= '' ( dbcs ) '' id= '' j.menu2 '' ... = > In the above editor , where ( dbcs ) is used , DBCS characters should be displayed correctly in the editor as well as correct DBCS chars as menu label in the run-time window . NOTES : RTP Test : ( E. Nair ) Verified with 136a and 137 . Fixed for all DBCS languages . Project name in DBCS is also displayed properly . However Project name in Plugin is a limitation and will not be resolved when compiled . 

Remembering the instruction:
Categorize the bug report into one of 2 categories:

0 = NOT SEVERE
1 = SEVERE[/INST]

Bug report:
 1 . Debug a program or two and let them terminated . Keep the old launches in the debug view . 2 . Debug a program to a breakpoint such that the stack frame will have a few variables to display in the variables view . 3 . With the suspended stack frame selected , and variables showing in the variables view , select `` Remove all terminated '' from the debug view . 4 . Note that the suspended stack frame is properly selected after the old launches are removed , but the variables view is empty . The user must manually reselect the stack frame to force the variables view to update . NOTES :

Bug report:
 The wizard banner should be reside acording to the text it is showing . - Open Java perspective - Create a new package . - Look the message in the new package dialog . In my WindowsNT machine I can see the message up to `` ... non-leaf '' and I ca n't read the end of the message . In my Linux box I can resize the dialog and read it . NOTES : KH ( 6/12/2001 8:06:07 AM ) Only two lines of text are available . ISV 's need to make sure their messages fit . Moving to JUI for comment . MA ( 07.08.2001 10:12:46 ) On windows the full text can be read . The line is now shorter , but I guess this problem will come again when NLS-ing , so maybe the workbench should prepare a solution as well . ( Tooltip , autowrapping .. ) KH ( 9/17/2001 10:00:59 AM ) Make sure that message area can handle two lines of text on Linux . Then move to `` Feature Request '' folder .
